13 years ago, an anonymous user on 4chan posted a full roadmap of Bitcoin‚Äôs critical price levels. Written back in 2012, the targets he shared have played out with almost uncanny accuracy. October 2019 at $10,400, February 2021 at $40,170, November 2021 at $67,930, the November 2022 bottom at $16,100, and September 2024 at $105,400. Every major level was hit.

The real question is what comes next. In the same post, the forecasts extend into 2026: $186,000 in January, $222,000 in February, followed by a sharp correction in March. Beneath it all, there‚Äôs a striking note: ‚ÄúBitcoin‚Äôs four year bear bull cycle is broken. A ten year super bull season has begun.‚Äù So now we have to ask ourselves. Are we looking at a 13 year old vision that was far ahead of its time, or a narrative designed to pull retail investors into the final stage of the cycle. For me, it‚Äôs never about who made the prediction, but what the market itself is telling us. What do you think?

Bitcoin faces key realized price levels


The indicator highlighted today is based on Bitcoin‚Äôs realized price, which reflects the average acquisition cost of $BTC across the network.


It includes three key levels:
‚Ä¢ Realized Price (purple)
‚Ä¢ Mid Band (grey)
‚Ä¢ Upper Band (red)


After breaking below the Mid Band, #Bitcoin could revisit the realized price near $56,000a level that has historically marked the end of bear markets.


However, a recovery above the Mid Band around $112,000 could open the door for a move toward the Upper Band near $225,000, a zone where Bitcoin has historically formed cycle tops.

A Quiet Shift in
$BTC Market Regime May Be
Underway
The #Bitcoin Regime Score is starting to hint at a meaningful structural change beneath the surface after a prolonged phase of bearish dominance. Instead of remaining deeply negative, the indicator has recently gravitated back toward its neutral baseline, suggesting that downside pressure on BTC is gradually losing persistence even though a confirmed bullish regime has yet to emerge.
In past cycles, extended periods below the zero line typically aligned with distribution-heavy phases and macro-driven risk-off conditions.
What stands out in the current structure is that bearish impulses are becoming shorter and less decisive, while bullish responses are appearing with increasing frequency. Although these rebounds remain limited, this behavior often signals that selling pressure in BTC is beinr absorbed and the market is transitioning more balanced regime.


On-chain data reinforces this interpretation.
Realized losses are easing, short-term holder distribution is slowing, and capital flows are beginning to look more neutral, pointing toward selective accumulation rather than forced selling. While macro uncertainty continues to act as a headwind, the regime score suggests BTC is no longer trapped in a strictly bearish, one-directional environment.
Although the indicator has not yet confirmed a sustained bullish regime, current readings imply that the most aggressive phase of downside risk may already be behind BTC. As long as the regime score continues to hold near or above its base level, the broader structure supports stabilization and recovery attempts rather than a renewed deterioration.

On December 26, 2025, a major structural pressure on Bitcoin expires.

Around $6.1B in upside call options vanish if $BTC  settles below $90K.
This isn‚Äôt a prediction. It‚Äôs mechanics.

Those calls sit above spot. If BTC doesn‚Äôt reach them, they expire worthless.
What matters is dealer hedging.

Dealers hedge sold calls by buying spot as price rises.
That flow has been capping upside for months not sentiment, structure.

At expiry, if BTC is below $90K, those hedges disappear.
Nothing is forced to sell. No liquidations.

The market doesn‚Äôt lose a floor.
It loses a ceiling.

Upside suppression turns off.

This doesn‚Äôt guarantee a rally or direction.
It simply resets the rules.

The real question comes after
once structure steps away, does real demand show up?

Derivatives Trading Reaches $86T in 2025 Volume   Global #cryptocurrency  derivatives activity has totaled $85.7 trillion in 2025, translating to daily average volume of $264.5 billion, CoinGlass reported. The expansion reflects growing institutional participation through regulated products and sophisticated #trading  strategies.   #Binance  processed $25.09 trillion in derivatives transactions, representing 29.3% of worldwide activity. Three other major venues, OKX, Bybit, and Bitget, combined for $27.2 trillion, with the top four platforms handling approximately 62% of total market flow.   The Chicago Mercantile Exchange expanded its footprint in BTC$BTC  contracts after surpassing Binance in open interest metrics during 2024. Regulated futures and options products drove gains for the traditional exchange as institutional pathways broadened throughout 2025.   Market structure shifted away from retail-dominated, high-leverage speculation toward hedging activity, basis trades, and ETF-linked positioning. CoinGlass noted this evolution introduced new risk dimensions through increased interconnectedness between platforms and deeper #leverage  utilization.

Each Bitcoin cycle shows a clear pattern: the move from cycle low to new all-time high becomes progressively less impulsive. The chart illustrates this well. If  $BTC had followed the trajectory of its first major low-to-ATH impulse (Blue), it would have reached roughly $601M by March 2024, not a typo.

If it had mirrored the second major impulse from Nov '11 to Nov '13 (Green), Bitcoin would have been around $9.4M by December 2024. And even using the least aggressive historical impulse (red), the Dec '18 to Nov '21 cycle, Bitcoin would be trading near $340K today.

Instead, the current chart structure-falling off a supportive trendline-- suggests that the next $40K of movement may be more likely to be downward than upward.

When Survival Comes at the Cost of Betrayal: Binance and the Sacrifice of Its Users in the UK


This move by Binance is nothing short of a deliberate sacrifice of its users for corporate survival a calculated and cold decision in which the interests of millions of users were crushed under regulatory pressure.


In the UK, instead of standing by the very users who built Binance‚Äôs liquidity, trust, and global dominance, the exchange chose the path of full surrender. By introducing a clearly timed program coinciding with the January 31 deadline and directing users toward tax-reporting tools, Binance effectively delivered a blunt message:
‚ÄúStay with us and submit to scrutiny, or leave.‚Äù


This was not merely ‚Äúregulatory cooperation‚Äù; it was a systematic transfer of risk and responsibility from the company to the user. Binance did not just facilitate data exposure it wrapped this act in the language of ‚Äúcompliance support,‚Äù executing a quiet but profound betrayal. Users who entered this ecosystem under the promise of financial freedom were instead turned into fuel for the survival of a multinational corporation.


What happened in the UK marks a turning point:
the moment Binance made it clear that, when pressured, users are the last priority. Trust breaks only once and once broken, it cannot be repaired.


The consequences will not be long in coming. The signs are already visible:
a wave of user exits from Binance is imminent.
Not driven by panic, but by awareness. Users now understand that when an exchange places its own survival above their assets and privacy, staying is no longer a choice it is a risk.


This decision may secure Binance‚Äôs short-term survival, but the cost is the loss of something no license, deal, or regulator can restore: trust.

How to Choose the Best Crypto Exchange for Bitcoin & Altcoins   Buying BTC$BTC  is straightforward. Picking the right exchange is where many people make costly mistakes. A strong platform offers fair prices, fast order execution, solid security, and smooth withdrawals. A weak exchange can hurt you through hidden fees, low liquidity, delayed payouts, or slow customer support. This guide explains how to choose the best crypto exchange for Bitcoin and altcoins, even if you‚Äôre a beginner.     Why Trading Volume and Liquidity Matter  Trading volume and liquidity show how active and dependable an exchange is. High liquidity usually means tighter spreads, less slippage, and quicker order fills.   CEX vs DEX: Which Should You Use?     Centralized Exchanges (CEX)  CEX platforms are easier for most users. They typically provide stronger liquidity, fiat deposit options, customer service, and extra tools like futures and copy trading. The downside is that your funds are held by the exchange unless you withdraw them to your own wallet.     Decentralized Exchanges (DEX)  DEX trading happens directly from your wallet through smart contracts. You stay in full control of your assets, but liquidity may be lower, slippage can be higher, and the risks are often greater. The major focus on 82K and 95K options for Bitcoin $BTC    suggests a general market sentiment leaning towards a potential downward move or a strategy to hedge against one.   However, the actual market action around options expiry is often characterized by range bound, choppy movement and can resolve in either direction depending on the balance of overall open interest and current price.    The market price often converges toward the "max pain" point at expiration the price at which the maximum number of options contracts expire worthless, maximizing seller profits. If the current price is above the max pain point >which is often the case in bullish markets <, the price might be drawn down. If the max pain is at or above the current price, the market might consolidate or even move up. Note the next move is DOWN.    STAY SHARP. #BTC Price Analysis#   #Macro Insights#
